Title: Cisco VPN Client Software Buffer Overflows Let Remote Users Cause Denial of Service Conditions
Version(s): 3.5.4 and prior versions, 3.6 and prior versions
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Cisco VPN Client software.  A remote user can trigger several buffer overflows to deny service to the VPN.
Cisco reported three vulnerabilities in their VPN Client software.  A remote user can send an Internet Key Exchange (IKE) packet with a Security Parameter Index (SPI) payload containing more than 16 bytes to trigger a buffer overflow in the VPN client software.  A remote user can send an IKE packet with more than 57 valid payloads to trigger a separate buffer overflow.  These buffer overflows can be exploited to cause denial of service conditions in the VPN Client software.  Also, a remote user can send a specially crafted packet with a zero length payload to cause the VPN Client software to consume 100% of CPU resources.
Impact': A remote user can disrupt a VPN or cause the Cisco VPN Client software to become unavailable.
Solution:
Cisco has released a fixed version (3.6), available now.  Also, the fix will be integrated in VPN Client version 3.5.4 or later, to be available by September 30, 2002.

The procedure to upgrade to the fixed software version on the various platforms is detailed in the documentation available:

http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/vpn/client/

Title: Cisco VPN Client (Linux/UNIX) Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Linux and UNIX versions of Cisco's VPN Client software.  A local user can gain root privileges on the system.
Cisco reported that a buffer overflow in the Cisco VPN Clients for Linux, Solaris, and Mac OS X platforms allows a local user to gain administrative privileges on the client system.

A remote user can supply a long profile name as an argument to the vpnclient command to trigger a buffer overflow, overwriting return values on the system's stack.  If the profile name is specially crafted, the local user could execute arbitrary code on the system.

By default, the vpnclient command is installed with set user id (suid) root permissions.  So, any arbitrary code executed will run with root privileges, giving the local user root access on the system.

According to Cisco, the Cisco VPN Clients for Windows platforms are not affected.

Cisco credits methodic and Josha Bronson of AngryPacket Security with reporting this flaw.  According to the Cisco advisory, AngryPacket Security will be publishing a security advisory at:

http://sec.angrypacket.com/advisories/0002_AP.vpnclient.txt

[Editor's note:  The AngryPacket Security advisory was not yet available at the time of this entry.]
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code on the system with root privileges, giving the local user root access on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (3.5.2), available free of charge to all affected customers.

Cisco has provided the following upgrade information:

Customers with contracts should obtain upgraded software through their regular update channels. For most customers, this means that upgrades should be obtained through the Software Center on Cisco's worldwide website at http://www.cisco.com/.

Customers whose Cisco products are provided or maintained through prior or existing agreement with third-party support organizations such as Cisco Partners, authorized resellers, or service providers should contact that support organization for assistance with the upgrade, which should be free of charge.

Customers who purchase direct from Cisco but who do not hold a Cisco service contract and customers who purchase through third-party vendors but are unsuccessful at obtaining fixed software through their point of sale should get their upgrades by contacting the Cisco Technical Assistance Center (TAC):

    * +1 800 553 2447 (toll-free from within North America)
    * +1 408 526 7209 (toll call from anywhere in the world)
    * e-mail: tac@cisco.com

See the vendor's advisory for additional information at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-unix-vpnclient-buffer-overflow-pub.shtml

Title: Tinc VPN Tunneling Software Lacks Packet Authentication Allowing Remote Users to Modify and Replay Tunnel Packets and Possibly Determine the Plain Text Contents
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the 'tinc' vpn tunneling software.  A remote user can modify packets, replay packets, and learn the pattern of the plain text.
It is reported that tinc does not provide packet authentication.  As a result, a remote user with access to the packet stream (i.e., somewhere along the transmission path) can modify the packet stream and choose the resulting plain text.

A remote user can cut encrypted data from one part of a packet and paste the data into another location.  Because both data sections have been encrypted using the CBC encryption mode and using the same key, the plain text data will not appear to be random.  If the user has some idea of what the plain text data might be, the user may be able to modify the encrypted packet such that the decrypted plain text will appear to be valid.

It is reported that the initialization vector (IV) used by tinc are random and, therefore, are not guaranteed to be unique.  An IV should never be repeated for a given key.  Because the IV used in tinc is 16 bits in length and given typical packet sizes, if tinc forwards approximately 255 packets, it is reported that there is a 50% probability that at least 2 packets will have the same IV (this is known as the birthday problem).  If an IV is repeated, this allows a remote user with access to the tunnel packets to potentially determine the key stream for a given key, which allows the user to determine the plain text.

It is reported that tinc does not provide any packet replay protection.  As a result, a remote user with access to the encrypted packets can capture the packets and replay them later and the destination will consider them as legitimate and decrypt them.

For example, a remote user can replay a TCP SYN packet to perform a SYN flood attack on a server behind the tinc peer entity.

[Editor's note:  The vendor's apparent web site (http://tinc.nl.linux.org/) could not be located at the time of this entry.  A vulnerable version of tinc is available from a mirror site (http://the.wiretapped.net/security/network-security/tinc/).]
Impact': A remote user can modify packets, replay packets, and learn the pattern of the plain text.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Check Point FireWall-1 SecuRemote VPN System Discloses Information About Valid Usernames
Version(s): tested on 4.1 SP4 (4185) VPN+Strong for Windows 2000, 4.1 SP4 (4185) VPN+Strong for Windows NT
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Check Point FireWall-1's SecuRemote VPN software.  A remote user can determine if a username is valid or not.
It is reported that when a remote user attempts to authenticate via the VPN-1 SecuRemote Authentication dialog box, a failed login response will indirectly indicate whether the username is incorrect or the password is incorrect, as the responses are different.

It is reported that if the username is valid and the password is incorrect, SecuRemote will return a dialog box with the message "Access denied by FireWall-1 authentication".  If the username is invalid, SecuRemote will apparently return a dialog box with the message "User <unknown_user> not found".

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can determine if a username is valid or invalid.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: SafeNet Soft-PK VPN Client Software Allows Local Users to Modify Locked VPN Policies
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in SafeNet (formerly IRE) Soft-PK virtual private networking (VPN) client software.  The flaw allows local users to modify certain VPN configuration information.
It is reported that Soft-PK stores policies that are specified as 'lockable' in plaintext.  The file can be edited and reloaded by a local user.  The software will still indicate that "This Policy Is Locked".

Example policy contents are shown below:

"IPADDR" =dword:0a810a01
"PORTNAME"="SQL"
"PORT"=dword:00000599

This apparently maps an SQL Port (1433) to box 10.129.10.1

"IPADDR" =dword:0a810a01
"PORTNAME"="DEMO"
"PORT"=dword:00000017

This apparently maps to port 23 on the same box.

This vulnerability reportedly does not allow a local user to obtain the VPN keys or to initiate unauthorized VPN connections.
Impact': A local user can modify the VPN client policy, including IP addresses and port numbers but not including keys.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Releases Fix) Re: Novell BorderManager VPN Services Can Be Crashed Remotely
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Novell BorderManager 3.5 VPN allowing a remote user to cause the client-to-server VPN feature to crash.
Client to site VPN services can reportedly be halted by a TCP SYN flood attack on port 353, causing the port to close and the service to cease functioning until the server is rebooted.  The port is used for key management.

After approximately 256 connections have been made to the port, the port will fail to respond to further TCP SYN requests and the server logs will indicate that all further connections are refused with the message "No more TCP/IP client connections are available."  The server must be rebooted or reinitialized.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the client-to-server VPN services to fail, requiring a reboot of the server to return to normal operation.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL or visit: http://support.novell.com/cgi-bin/search/tidfinder.cgi?2958995

The server must be rebooted or reinitialized. The vendor has reportedly been notified.

The Source Message contains demonstration exploit code.
Impact': A remote user can cause the client-to-server VPN services to fail, requiring a reboot of the server to return to normal operation.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  However, the author of the report provides some workaround recommendations.  See the source message.
